original_title: Sri Lanka manufacturing up, retail trade down in March 2023 : PMI
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s manufacturing activity saw a recovery in March 2023 ahead of a traditional New Year in April along with most services but wholesale and retail trade was down, according to a Purchasing Managers’ Index.
Employment continued to fall with attrition and people moving abroad according to the survey of purchasing managers conducted by the central bank.

Sri Lanka is suffering the worst currency crisis in the history of the islands intermediate regime central bank which printed large volumes of money over two years to target an output gap, despite it being probably illegal under the existing monetary law which is focused on stability.

the International Monetary Fund gave technical assistance to calculate potential output giving the data driven impetus to print money, critics say. Outgap gap targeting is to be legalized in a new monetary law, along with dual anchor conflicts.

“The increase in New Orders and Production was mainly driven by the manufacture of food & beverages sector, where many respondents mentioned that they experienced a relatively higher demand compared to previous months to cater for the upcoming festive season,” the statement said.

“However, Employment continued to decline mostly due to non-replacement of retirements and resignations. Further, Stock of Purchases declined in March as well, since some firms used their stocks of raw materials delaying new purchases with the anticipation of a decline in raw material prices in the period ahead.”

Sri Lanka lifted a surrender rule in March which had kept the rupee down, and there was an appreciation of the domestic currency. The central bank had earlier hiked rates to reduce domestic credit and phased out money printing, generating a balance of payments surplus before the surrender rule was lifted.
“..[F]inancial services sub-sector continued to improve with the increases in deposits, while other personal activities sub-sector also exhibited a significant improvement,” the statement said.

Rising banks deposits and reduced credit, helps trigger a balance of payments surplus as long when net open market operations of the central bank is deflationary. There is a liquidity shortage in the banking system allowing liquidity created from dollar purchases to be automatically mopped up.
“Meanwhile, human health, insurance, education and professional services sub-sectors also recorded slight increases during the month,” the statement said.
“However, business activities related to wholesale and retail trade sub-sector continued to deteriorate despite some improvements seen ahead of the festive season.”
The statement did not say why wholesale and retail trade continued to decline. (Colombo/Apr22/2023)
